author: PETER SUROWSKI
title: BEAUMONT: Officials push for second jury trial of former officer who blinded woman
text:
By PETER SUROWSKI / STAFF WRITER
Published: Oct. 9, 2015 Updated: 5:47 p.m. TIMELINE Feb. 21, 2012: Altercation between Beaumont Police officer Enoch Clark and Monique Hernandez
April 2012: Grand jury indicts Clark
May 29, 2013: Hernandez files civil complaint against Clark and city of Beaumont
May 20, 2014: Mistrial is declared, jury is hung
Dec. 20, 2014: Civil suit settles with Hernandez and her family being awarded $18.5 million
Prosecutors are pushing to bring a former Beaumont police officer back to trial after the jury on the first trial failed to reach a unanimous conclusion on whether the man blinded a woman when he used pepper spray during an arrest in 2012, officials said.
If found guilty, Enoch Clark could face a sentence ranging from misdemeanor probation to seven years in custody. He is due in court Thursday to address a motion by his attorney that his indictment be thrown out due to lack of reasonable cause, court documents show.
Clark was tried by the Riverside County District Attorney’s Office on charges of assault under the color of authority, assault with a less lethal weapon, use of force causing serious bodily injury and assault with force likely to cause great bodily injury. Meanwhile, the victim, Monique Hernandez, launched a civil suit in May 2013 that ended in 2014 with a $18.5 million settlement against the former officer and Beaumont, records and Hernandez’s attorney, Milton Grimes, said.
Clark pulled over the victim, Monique Hernandez, on Feb. 21, 2012, after receiving a call from her family reporting a disturbance. While trying to arrest her, Clark fired a handgun-like pepper spray device called a JPX into her eyes.
Hernandez was left permanently blind.
Clark was taken to court once, but in August 2014, after a week of deliberation, a mistrial was declared when the jury was hung with 10 in favor of conviction and two against.
During Clark’s trial, prosecutors said he fired the pepper-spray gun at Hernandez’s eyes at a distance of less than a foot. The weapon, which uses gunpowder to propel the spray from the muzzle at a rate of speed about 400 mph, sliced Hernandez’s right eye in half, fractured her right orbital bone and severed the optic nerve in her left eye.
Hernandez and her family are still participating in the civil suit by providing deposition. The pepper-spray gun manufacturer is being brought in as a third-party defendant by the city of Beaumont in the civil suit, according to Hernandez’s attorney.
As the criminal case against Clark inches forward, the Hernandez family is hoping for a trial with a conviction, Hernandez’s attorney said.
“(Hernandez) is an amazing person. She’s not angry… she doesn’t have any hostility,” Grimes said in a recent interview. “She wants justice and thinks (Clark) should be punished, but she doesn’t have any bitterness.”
Hernandez and her family are receiving the $18.5 million settlement on a monthly basis, but it is no replacement for her vision, the attorney said.
“Would you accept $18 million for your vision?” he said. “Of course not. Nobody would.”
Clark’s attorney said in an emailed statement that the former officer had no idea the spray could do that kind of damage.
“Clark and the Beaumont Police Department were taught by the manufacturer that the JPX was no different from regular aerosol OC (oleoresin capsicum, or pepper) spray,” Steven Sanchez said.
